characters: DEAR JERK, IT'S GREAT YOU COULD USE UP TWO PARKING SPACES
THERE SHE IS, TOP OF THE GULCH
A NIGHT LIKE THIS. EVER HEAR OF THE JOY OF SHARING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a sign reading "Pleasant Valley Dream Homes", a pict postcard boulevard of mini mansions curves into infinity. Each home is brand new. Each has the same size lawn, the shrubs, the same satellite dish. Each has an indistinguishable car parked in the driveway. All the homes have Christmas decorations, Christmas trees with baubles, lights and Christmas stars sitting proudly the top. The doors have Christmas wreaths. The sheen of a recent rainfall makes all the surfaces gli in the lights. We halt outside one house. 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This home too seems perfect until we notice the Christmas star has fallen from the top of the tree and lies reflect itself in a puddle on the wet lawn. Suddenly we hear the sound of wings fluttering and see an among the branches of the Christmas tree. It rises from t tree then swoops down to the lawn where it sweeps a mouse from the grass. The owl then soars off, casting a magnifi shadow of her wings across the house, and disappears with it's prey into the woods behind. Curtains part at a downstairs window. The silhouette of a appears bathed in the blue glow of a computer screen. He draws the curtains once again and disappears. 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sneak between curtain and window ledge into a home off fitted out with a flat screen TV and a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENNETH, a forty something ex-jock with a once handsome f pours a beer into a crystal brandy glass. Kenneth's eyes glued to the computer screen where stock numbers scroll endlessly down. He highlights a set of numbers and stands abruptly from his chair elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps back onto a A CHILD'S DOLL, crushing it underfoot. ebullient mood changes quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! DELLA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of footsteps are followed by the door opening. DELLA peers into the room. She's a diminutive blonde in h thirties with fine features and a fading Southern accent. She's pulling a coat on over a white shirt and jeans. She sees the broken doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOT, KENNETH! That's Tammi's favorite doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks in, picks up the doll and tries to fix its squa face. He turns back to the computer guiltily, takes a sip beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should just swear properly and get it over with. Do you think the kids don't know what you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up, his face is ruddy - the face of someone who dri too much. He turns back towards her. She ignores him, continues to try fix the doll. His eyes linger on her coa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going out again? What is it tonight? Auto Mechanics for Dummies? The bored housewives' reading group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He averts his eyes back to the screen then turns back to at her once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a new one for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles sardonically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group therapy for women who always have the curse. There's a Tuesday night class at the Pleasant Valley Episcopalian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth clearly thinks he's funny. Della glares a warning him and bites her lip to stop a vitriolic response escapi from her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the mall for wrapping paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trail of kids mess in the hallway behind Della catches Kenneth's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do all day, Della honey? Cause it sure isn't keeping house. This place is an eyesore. I'm mortgaged up to the eyeballs for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sad eyes meet hers in confrontation. Della, determine not to engage, averts hers. Kenneth, unable to contain himself, faces her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's not like you're at some salon fancying up your hair or nails like the other men's wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts a strand of her limp fair hair and lets it drop, looks right in her tired face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time I saw you wearing something sexy was our engagement party. God, Della, you used to be hot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bites her lip again, but this time to try stop the te He turns away, in an attempt to conceal his own sadness. She walks away clutching the doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the twins to bed by eight. Give them a chocolate cookie with their milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Della. Della honey, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's already left the room. He watches her pick up a of car keys from a dresser in the dimly lit hallway. Her knuckles are white as she clenches her fingers around the Kenneth turns back to his computer. 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della climbs the stairs. Framed photographs on the wall t the public story of her life. The engagement to Kenneth, their wedding, the birth of the twins, Kenneth's graduati Kenneth as a sixth grade football star, Della on the farm Ohio with her horse, a really young Della playing basebal with her father. We linger on a photo of a very pretty tw something Della in a little black dress. 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRI and TAMMI are seven year old twins with the delicat blue eyed blonde looks of their Mother. Della stands in the doorway and watches them. Tammi is lying on her girlish bed drawing with crayons. Terri's toy dinosaurs are destroying Tammi's heirloom dol house, starting with the furniture. She steps into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy can I get an American Girl for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a raptor dinosaur, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better leave Santa a note. It's only three days until Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives them each a kiss, breathing in their scent she loves so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Mommy? Scene 5 Page 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mall. One chocolate cookie each and then Daddy will read you a bedtime story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy's stories are lame. I want you to read us a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Mommy, the one about the pirates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the cowgirls. Diamond Lil and Slingshot Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night I'll read you the best bedtime story in the whole world. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della gives them a little wave and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check in on you both when I get back. (beat) To make sure you're sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. Terri's already turned back to his dinosaurs. Tammi runs toward her and gives her the drawing she's bee working on. It's a drawing of a stick figure family holdi hands. The words "Mommy, we love you" are written across cloudy night sky like big stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tammi, it's wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della doesn't have time to look at it properly so she fol the drawing up and puts it in her pocket. She kisses Tamm again and turns to leave. Tammi's eyes follow her mother she walks away. 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della checks her watch and hurries down the stairs. 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on the bottom stair to pull on a pair of boots. boots are well worn but polished to a gleam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind her, an antique grandfather clock strikes seven p. The sound of gun shots fades in from the TV in Kenneth's office. 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della collects a packet of cookies from a cabinet. She lo at the pile of dirty dinner dishes in the sink then looks away. 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della leaves the cookies at the bottom of the stairs and opens the front door. The TV blares out some action flick from Kenneth's ajar door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della is met by a blast of cold evening air and the eerie silence of the suburbs. She closes the door softly behind and rushes along the path to the driveway where the famil black Ford Explorer is parked. She CHIRPS the remote and quickly climbs in. 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della inserts the key and turns it in the lock.    The ca sputters in defiance against the cold night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car sputters again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'MON...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a massive exertion, the car engine turns over and th vehicle starts. She sighs with relief. She turns the heat up high and warms her hands at the ven pauses to look at her home through the car window. For a second, in an upstairs window, she sees a reflection of Tammi. She smiles, then looks at the house and lawn and the Christmas tree. She notices the fallen star, is about to out of the car to retrieve it, but decides it's too cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow creeps across her face as she pulls the stick in reverse and backs up. 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow her as she backs up, pushes into drive and head slowly down the boulevard. The road is empty. All the cars are neatly tucked away in their driveways and it looks like no one's out tonight. S makes a right turn onto. 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows the road as it curves around a long row of endlessly monotonous houses. In the distance, we can see gates of Pleasant valley gated community. 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slows down, rolls down her window and swipes a chub c against the security panel. The gates slowly open. She dr through. The gates close behind her. She rolls the window and makes a left turn onto. 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road is wider and framed on either side by the high w of gated communities. A Ford Explorer just like hers pass in the opposite direction. 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della smiles mysteriously, reaches into the glove compart with her free hand. She pushes aside a bunch of car paper flare, pulls out a check wallet hidden underneath - her secret hiding place for: A nice pack of Marlboros. She smiles again - the smile of secret smoker. She presses the cigarette lighter into the dashboard. The lighter pops out. She tips out a cigarette, sees a sticky note attached to the interior foil. Scrawled in me handwriting are the words - YOU ARE SUPPOSED TO BE QUITTI DELLA HONEY. XOXO KENNETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get right on that Kenneth honey. AFTER you stop drinking. Scene 16Page 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rips the note off, stuffs it in her purse, lights the cigarette. She inhales deeply.     We see the pleasure written acros face. 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few cars pass Della in the night. Their lights are like torches in the suburban wilderness. 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the familiar ring of a cellular phone. Della has programmed one of those "oh so cute" recognizable tunes i it, like the "William Tell overture". Della holds the wheel with one hand and fumbles through h purse with the other. She eventually locates the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della, it's Mary Messina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della rolls her eyes.     This is not a welcome call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get my cell number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della balances the phone while she drags on her cigarette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called Kenneth at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great.   She exhales sharply. Scene 18Page 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how'd that go? Did he give you an earful for disturbing his ninety ninth viewing of Lethal Weapon Four? Mary giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Della. Kenneth is always charming. At least to me. The car flashes past the decorated sign for a local schoo Before Della can stop herself, the words are out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, with the way you flaunt your double D boob job at the free fun PTA events that's hardly a surprise. Fortunately for her the phone happens to make a deep meta distortion at that moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh nothing, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got lucky with that one. Patricia Ellis says he's the best looking guy in Pleasant Valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that wouldn't be hard. Mary, do you need something? Cause I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, are you going to Tool School tomorrow? Mary giggles at her own joke. Della sighs.    THIS is why she is having her serenity interrupted? Scene 18Page 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOOL SCHOOL?, Ouch, Mary. Do It Yourself Mechanics is without a doubt the most interesting thing in my life right now. (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carry my beloved toolbox in the trunk at all times. The desolate road disappears behind Della.    She passes roadside memorial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just joking, Della. You know me. I pre-paid ten classes and only made it to two. If you are going I could use a ride. I'd hate to miss another class. If Della was going before, she's not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mary, I'm skipping this week. Kenneth's parents are coming to stay for Christmas. You know how it is. A red light looms ahead. Della slows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's too bad. Maybe Patricia Ellis will be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You check with her, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. God bless you and your family. Christmas lights outline a few distant houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too. (Under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bah Humbug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della stops at the red light. She clicks off the phone an lets it lay on her lap. She rakes about among a bunch of kids stuff in the back s casts aside, an anorak, mittens, a sock. She finds what she's looking for, a bottle of water, caug on the bar under the passenger seat. It's only a third fu but she takes a sip, recoils from its coldness. The light changes.   She throws the bottle into the back 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas lights: reindeer, stars, even the American flag the black night. 20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della picks up the phone and pushes a few keys. She has n dialed enough to make a full phone call when we hear the phone RING on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cellular 411 connect. How may I direct your call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Learning Academy. Spring Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hold for that number. Della slows down for another red light. She's at a wide crossroads where the housing development abruptly ends and a wasteland of deforestation begins. A billboard for another new housing development announces "GREEN STREET DREAM HOMES - Investment Opportunities". Waiting for the light at the opposite side of the road fr Della is a car with an animal cadaver strapped to the roo Della tries not to look at it. A recording breaks into the moment just as the light ahea changes to green. Scene 20Page 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recording)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press your pound key now to connect with your request. Della presses the pound key and drives straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learning Academy, this is Meghan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Meghan.     It's Della Myers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hey. You calling about Spanish for Beginners? You know that Tom cancelled 'cause of New Year's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hold, I have another call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Frustrated, Della turns on the radio.    It is some innoc local ad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasant Valley Dream Homes. The lowest crime rate in the US. Call 1- 800-SAFE. Della switches stations trying to find something she like She gives up and waits for Meghan to return. The car flas past construction road signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Della ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you leave word for Mike. I'm going to miss tomorrow's Mechanic's class. It's just the one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone misses that class at least once. Scene 20Page 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess some people find it boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see you the first week in January then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you will...unless I run off and become an outlaw or something. Meghan giggles. We hear the familiar beep of another call coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too. Della clicks the phone over to the incoming call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Della... it's Cassie. Cassie's voice is almost lost in the din of her surroundi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? Grand Central Station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, I'll take the phone outside. A loud noise appears out of nowhere. 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car SCREECHES to a halt. Della almost didn't see it. is at a railroad crossing, the third car in line, and she almost rear-ended the car in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Della.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost rear-ended a car. Cassie? The phone cuts out. The train starts to go laboriously pa Carriage after carriage of brand name building materials new housing developments. Della lights another cigarette. She turns on the radio again, finds a station playing "Th Sound of Silence". The crossing gates go up.   The cars ahead of her start. Della shifts into drive. The phone rings its special tune again.   Della turns the volume of the radio down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Cassie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm over at Southeast Plaza. What was it we need to get for Pilates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? One of those rubber balls, I think. I'm headed over there now. Ran out of Christmas wrapping paper. Would you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hell here tonight. Everyone and their uncle is at the mall. Della's phone makes a loud, distorted noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw shoot. My cell battery's dying. She rifles about in the passenger seat, leans over to the back, and rifles about there among the kids toys, gives u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, I must have left the charger in the other car. Scene 21Page 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to pick up something for you while I'm here? Cassie's kind offer almost reduces Della to tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No....I'm just. I mean I'm. Oh nothing. The phone beeps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your phone's breaking up Della. I'm not joking when I say it's packed over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be that bad? The light up ahead turns amber then red.    Della stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we meet somewhere for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but a latte's about the best they can do in this mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A latte's fine. Let's meet at the fountain opposite Victoria's Secret. The light changes and Della drives up and over a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good. The phone beeps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My battery's going. I'm a block away. See you in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay but I won't be able to wait very .... The phone beeps again.   It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della lets it drop onto her lap. She opens the window and flicks out the remains of her cigarette. She waves her ha to fan away the smoke. She closes the window again. She's about to hide her cigarettes again when she changes mind and stuffs them directly into her purse. As the car approaches the cusp of the hill she slows down stare ahead. 22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southeast Plaza.   The day before Christmas Eve. Hell on Earth. A large, sprawling parking lot full of cars.   Nothing bu cars. A sea of cars. 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a second, Della contemplates turning around and leavi The guy in the SUV behind her beeps. She steps on the gas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay! Her car careens slowly down hill to the lot. 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road spits her out in front of the Mall entrance wher revellers and shoppers are entering and exiting. Della follows several cars down the first long row of par cars. The asphalt is wet from the recent rainfall. Puddles gath in its dents and hollows. She passes car after densely parked car. There isn't a sp in sight. She reaches the end of the row and indicates le turns down the next row, ploughs through a rain puddle wh splashes up onto a MOTHER who's walking her little GIRL a BOY back to their car. The woman shouts at Della.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch where you're going! Della rolls down her window. Scene 24Page 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry! The Mother's weighed down with shopping bags. She glares Della and drags her kids across the aisle in front of her Della sighs, drives down the second aisle. An Escape midway down the row blocks traffic. It's waitin for a Subaru to pull out so it can take the spot. 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky son of a ..... The Subaru exits the spot slowly. Della taps her impatien fingers against the steering wheel. 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Subaru pulls away and the Escape snaps into the empty space. Della continues her journey down to the end of the row. T are no spaces. 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It dawns on her that parking up close to the entrance jus isn't going to happen. She takes the last puff from the cigarette burning out in the ashtray. 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using the side aisle she scoots past row three and four a they all flow one way. At the end of this row a confrontation is brewing. Severa cars block each other. Horns blast. An angry DRIVER screa at another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you think you're gonna steal my spot, think again, asshole! 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della looks on for a moment at the confrontation. She gri out the stub of her cigarette into the ashtray, slams it closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della shakes her head and turns left into row five. Jesus Are there really this many cars in Pleasant Valley? It's brand new Mall and the only one around for miles but this ridiculous. Della reaches the end of row five quickly. She guessed th wouldn't be a spot so she's driving faster. She notices a portly middle aged RENT-A-COP directing tra ahead. She lowers her window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? The Rent-a-Cop stops directing and approaches the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where I can definitely find parking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing close by. Even the valet's backed up. You might want to try further out. He points off into the distance through the sea of cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But be willing to walk. A car waiting behind Della honks its horn loudly and the A-Cop saunters away. Della guns the Ford down row eight. 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of this row, Della decides to take the Rent-A- Cop's advice. She makes another left at the aisle and ski several more rows. She heads down to the third from last 31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars... cars... If she never sees another car it will be soon. Della spies a spot, halfway down the row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She guns the engine, gets ready to pull in and is DENIED. Somebody has parked an enormous old gold Plymouth so badl it's taking up TWO spaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable! She brakes in the nick of time and sighs deeply. She's starting to lose her patience now. 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With no options left, Della heads down to the very last r More cars fill the spaces. And then - two spots. The last two spots in the car park. They overlook undeveloped land just beyond the mall. Small concrete bumps signify the en each space. 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della whips the car into the first one. She sighs with relief as she straightens the car up into the spot. She s for a second trying to calm herself down but it isn't working. She reaches for another cigarette, then, talks herself out of it. She fastens her coat, grabs her purse and opens the door. 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps down from the Ford right into a puddle. The dirty w splashes up onto her pants.

dialogues.speaker: GREAT
dialogues.text: She shakes the boot off and looks over at the mall. It's least a half mile away, glimmering in the distance. She sets off marching across the lot, taking what seems t the most direct route. Maybe she can shake off this mood the time she gets inside. She passes the Plymouth, turns, stares back at it. The ca dirty gold and riddled with rust holes with a vinyl roof that's almost peeled away. She walks up close, tries to decipher the plate, but it's caked with mud. Annoyance rises like bile in her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds herself reaching into her purse, rummaging for small notebook, then a sharpie. She leans on the car as s writes.

dialogues.speaker: A CONCERNED FRIEND.
dialogues.text: She scans her words.    Pretty good! Della rips the piece of paper from the notebook, folds th note several times and slides it under the Plymouth's windshield wipers. The driver can't miss it. She smiles. That felt good! Head held high she marches on towards the Mall. The CAMERA pulls up so we can see the mall, see Della marching across the lot, see the crowds of shoppers enter and exiting the mall, and get the feeling that maybe some just saw her. 35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoppers are buying freshly felled Christmas trees from a vendor. Della squeezes past and pushes through the mall doors. 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave of heat and Christmas lights hits Della. A wave of nausea follows as she is swallowed by the crowd of last minute shoppers. Distorted muzak versions of Christmas so seep from invisible speakers. Della gets caught up in a line of children waiting to see Santa in his grotto. She squeezes through and makes her w towards the fountain outside of Victoria's Secret. En route she is stopped by a perfume sales lady who spray her wrist with perfume before she has time to protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a classic revival of Chanel No.5. We have a wonderful Christmas Special on offer at Macy's. She hands Della a sample and flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Della arrives at the fountain. A piddling jet of dirty wa gurgles from the mouth of a bored mermaid and streams dow into the shallow pool full of nickels and dimes. She scan the crowd but there's no sign of Cassie. Della sits at the edge of the fountain. She checks her wa then checks out the people milling around in front of Victoria's Secret, where mannequins in skimpy festive underwear are propped seductively in the window displays. Still no sign of Cassie. She's about to make a wish and t a quarter into the fountain when a Red Cross worker shake her "Save the Children" tin at her. Della sticks the quar into the tin instead. 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della wanders the aisles of festive colored undies watchi men pick out slinky lingerie for their partners and women examine slim fit underpants and padded bras. She notices a pure silk black teddy, very classic, no fri She lifts it from the rail and holds it against herself i front of the mirror, tries to imagine herself in it. A young SALES ASSISTANT approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pure silk, the last one in our classic black label collection. Would you like me to fix you a changing room? Della checks the size tag. It reads 36C, two sizes too bi And the price tag next to it. Ouch! It's expensive for Victoria's Secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. Not my size. She gestures to her small boobs, smiles and hands the ted to the sales assistant. She quickly leaves the shop. 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della checks one last time at the fountain for Cassie. Sh tries to dodge the crowd as she makes her way toward a generic coffee shop. Maybe Cassie will be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harried women and a few men, clutching bags full of gifts impatient children, stand on line for their favorite drug Della squeezes past them to look for Cassie. Every seat a every booth is full but there's no sign of her friend. Della joins the line. She finds herself biting at her nai a bad habit since childhood. A woman in front of her places an order then moves on to pick up area. Della moves up to the counter to where an OVERWEIGHT SALES ASSISTANT waits on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A latte please? She notices some chocolate covered biscotti on the counte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a chocolate biscotti. She catches sight of herself in the mirror behind the counter. Kenneth's right about one thing, she looks awful

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitter or Milk chocolate? Seeing herself in the mirror changes her mind about the biscotti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, just the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della, two L's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four dollars and seventy nine cents. Della pushes the money towards her and waits for her coff When it finally shows up her name is spelled DELA. She si and checks the line for Cassie as she leaves the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She passes a hair salon and presses her face to the steam windows. Inside, women are getting their hair styled and their nails manicured at the same time. Della looks down at her bitten nails but just can't bring herself to go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della, is that you? She turns around to see LYNN MONROE, a pretty, well groom redhead about her age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn Monroe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was you, Della. I haven't seen you since college. You left to marry some handsome jock and we never heard from you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that. Do you live around here now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and I just bought this divine house in Pleasant Valley. Do you know it? Great for the kids. Della nods but Lynn keeps speaking. Della sips on her lat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first time I've left the doors unlocked since I was a child growing up in the Midwest. David's been promoted to VP of United Motors so it's all happening for us. But enough of me. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we have two kids. Twins, Tammi and Terri. Lynn becomes distracted, focusing on her perfect reflecti in the steamy glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why that's fantastic. Listen Della, it's been great talking to you but I have to go get my hair done! David and I are going out tomorrow night for a romantic dinner. I just bought this gorgeous teddy from Victoria's Secret. She opens the bag and Della sees it's the black teddy she eyed earlier. Della smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope we bump into each other again soon, sweetie. Merry Christmas She gives Della a fake kiss and rushes into the salon. Della chucks her half finished coffee into a nearby trash and walks on through the Mall. 41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della enters a pharmacy. She locates the wrapping paper aisle. She sweeps up a bunch of rolls at three for ninety nine cents. She feels the texture of the paper, it's thin looks gaudy so she puts them all back. Instead she select some expensive gold paper with silver embossed stars and matching silver ribbon. She then finds some jolly childre wrapping with Christmas tree designs and a great big red She browses through the aisles of cards. She sees some cu cards for the twins and then arrives at the "To my Darlin Husband at Christmas" section. She opens some of the card and recoils from the sentiments contained inside. She catches a groomed BLONDE HOUSEWIFE staring at her and corrects her facial expression from one of revulsion to a complicit Stepford smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pity they don't have any "To a bastard at Christmas" cards. The woman looks at Della like she's a lunatic. Della chuc to herself. She finds the feminine hygiene aisle and picks up a pack regular tampax. She gathers her stuff and carries it to the checkout wher TIRED MAN and his TWO KIDS wait before her on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man tries to remove a snow globe, with a tiny house a Christmas tree inside, from the clutches of his young son The child starts bawling. The man ends up buying the snow globe to placate the child. It's Della's turn. The PHARMACY SALES ASSISTANT smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect timing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God planned it for Christmas Day just to tick me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty dollars and sixty nine cents

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She packs Della's stuff into paper bags. Della hands her card over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot less crowded now. The melancholy "Home for Christmas" plays. She follows the ladies sign to the entr to the bathroom, only to find an "Out of Order" sign on t door. She sees a cleaning lady in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come the ladies' bathroom is out of order on a night like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The    cleaning lady disappears through the bathroom door her    cart of cleaning utensils. Della looks down the le the    huge mall and decides she's not even going to try the    other bathroom. She can wait until she gets home. She makes her way towards the exit, pulls her coat in tig and braces herself for the cold front outside. Scene 43Page 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of CAROL SINGERS sing "Silent Night".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent Night. Holy Night. All is calm. All is bright. Della listens for a moment. Their voices are clear and bright. Behind them she can see the Christmas tree vendor bag up left over trees. Della's hands start to pinch with the cold. She gathers her bags of wrapping paper and sets off acros the emptying lot. The last of the shoppers rush across th car park to find their cars. It's pretty dark between the pole lamps and the car lights. She slows down at the second aisle for a car to pass, the another. Marches on. A man and his little girl walk past. He nods. Della's eye linger on the little girl. She really wants to get home t the kids. The singers' voices echo faintly through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy infant so tender and mild. She walks faster, almost at a dash. Where is her car? Even further out than she remembered, that's for sure. A car alarm goes off in the distance. The alarm stops at last as Della approaches the outer sec of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shepherds quake at the sight. Glories beam from heaven afar. She cuts between some of the cars in row eight. Zigzags across aisle nine. Notices the Plymouth still parked ahea She stops for a split second. Then approaches. Glances at windshield. The note is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it fell off. She checks the ground around the car. sign of it. She shrugs, who cares anyway? She cuts across the next aisle. It's almost empty. And th one after that. Her Explorer is sandwiched between two ca in this otherwise empty row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent Night. Holy Night She chirps the remote twice and pops the trunk, places th bags inside. She slams the trunk closed and hurries to th drivers' side, climbs in, pulling the door closed behind 44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della turns the key in the ignition and presses in the lighter. She lights a cigarette and inhales as she lets t car warm up for 30 seconds. She rests the cigarette in the ashtray while she releases hand brake and slips the gear into reverse. The interior her car is suddenly flooded with light from another car's headlights. She glances in the rear view mirror. A car is blocking her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord! What now? She steps on the brake and waits for the car to move. But it doesn't. Its headlights flick to full beam blindin her view in her car mirrors. She honks her horn. The car still doesn't move. Della's really angry now. She slips the gearshift into pa and steps out of her car. 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della squints in the blinding headlights. The front of th car looks familiar. It's the gold Plymouth! Two unseen car doors click open and clunk shut again. The lights abruptly go out. Della blinks, her eyes try to adjust to the dim mercury illumination from a pole lamp a car lengths away. She uneasily turns back to her car. Scene 45Page 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a gun. It's a young male voice. The statement stops Della dead i her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's about I aim it at your pussy first? The words are emphasized by another boy's shrill giggling Della freezes. This can't be happening! Her eyes are adjusting. The glare phantoms drift out to t limit of her peripheral vision and vanish. She sees three boys in front of her, then a fourth, but s doesn't see any gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you playing at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust the nigga, we not playin'. HUEY is a sweet-faced African-American decked out in a hi hop style. He's small and skinny and can't be more than eighteen. He's playing to CHUCKIE who's twenty-one and lo like a marine gone AWOL. Bracketing them is VINH, a ninet year old Asian punk and TOMAS, twenty, a Latino runaway i American Idol T-shirt. Della's eyes drift across the group. She suppresses a hysterical giggle but can't resist smarting off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you? The world's first homeless United Nations Boy Band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah. We just wanna do shows and bone hoes. Huey messes with his zipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a song fo' yo. It's called "shut up bitch and eat a dick". Huey and Tomas snigger. Vinh stares at the asphalt. Scene 45Page 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when yo done eating we gonna staple that bitch mouth closed. Chuckie nudges Huey and Tomas, steps towards Della.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, my little brothers. The boys fall silent.   Vinh lights a cigarette. Huey shi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gitting cold, Chuckie. Game's not worth the dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie? At least your parents have a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents? I ain't got no parents. I named myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Huey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab my parka from the back seat. He pinches Huey's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And smile, playa. The dopes game and the game's dope. Chuckie leads Huey a few steps to the Plymouth. Huey duck into the back seat. Chuckie keeps his eyes fixed on Della

dialogues.text: You got a beef with us, Mrs. Podunk? Della looks defiantly back without answering. Chuckie run his fingers along the hood of the rusty gold Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you put yo hands on my ride! Now, I don't know how you was raised but, in my world, laying your hands on someone else's shit is crossing their line! Then, you go slipping an incendiary note up under my windscreen wipers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that'd UCKIE(CONT'D) CH be an invitation to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: war to me and my ghetto soldiers.

dialogues.text: What? If you hadn't parked like an asshole, we wouldn't be arguing about it right now. Vinh inhales sharply from his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoah Lady!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep right on talking that gang a shit, chinga. Yo crimes against the click are digging yo grave deep. Della's eyes quickly scan the group for sign of the gun. can't see one so she gambles they're just mouthing off an makes her move.

dialogues.text: Go to hell! Della turns towards her car. Huey steps out of the shadow wearing Chuckie's parka hood up covering his face, startl Della.

dialogues.text: We already in hell. Della sidesteps him, reaches the back of her car.

dialogues.text: Any trouble here, ma'am? Everyone turns to see a Rent-a-Cop, puffed up like a pige in his fur trimmed jacket and Russian style cap. It's the same guy Della approached earlier when she was looking fo spaces except this time his hand is laying casually acros the unsnapped holster flap at his hip.

dialogues.text: Not if these delinquents move their barge so I can back up.

dialogues.text: How about it, boys? Chuckie smiles and nudges Tomas who starts dancing in a r mocking manner imitating the Rent-a-Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie pulls a gun from deep in his army jacket pocket a points it straight at the Rent-a-Cop's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. We not in the mood. Chuckie looks at his friends for approval. Huey laughs ag shrill. Tomas grins. Vinh hunches and looks around. The Rent-a-Cop backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Jesus' sake. Tomas takes off a small crucifix from around his neck and dangles it in front of the Rent-a-Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say yo prayers old man. Chuckie grins at Della while keeping the gun pointed stra at the Rent-a-Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These Rent-a-Pig companies are too lame to give their foot soldiers any ammo. Liability laws and all that. Tough shit! The Rent-a-Cop goes for his pistol anyway. Chuckie shoots him in the face. THIS MOMENT CHANGES EVERYTHING. We thought Della was in trouble but now we know she is. The bullet hits the Rent-A-Cop in the forehead. Blood spu from the exit wound. He slumps to the asphalt like a marionette whose strings have just been cut. Bullet smoke hangs in the air where he once stood. Smoke too blackens bullets entry wound. Blood puddles out from the back of h head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck! It's clear that Chuckie's been acting harder than he is. hand that holds the gun is trembling. The color drains fr his face. All stand riveted in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deathly silence follows. The carol singers can be heard the distance faintly finishing up Silent Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep in heavenly peace. Sleep in heavenly peace. Chuckie looks to his friends for support but none is forthcoming. The Rent-A-Cop's body twitches. Chuckie hesitates then raises the gun. He aims and fires. shot shatters the top of the Rent-A-Cop's head. Chuckie flinches, closes his own eyes in reflex. Della swallows. If she started screaming now, she may nev stop. She spins instead and makes for her car door. She's dead if she doesn't get out of here and she knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's busting a move! Chuckie opens his eyes. Vinh points to Della. Chuckie looks over and sees Della disappear through the d of her Explorer. Agitation overwhelms him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't going nowhere. We got her Ford blocked in, right? He looks at Vinh who nods then at Huey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing. Chuckie looks back at Vinh then over at Tomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Dar candela por el culo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can just put one through her windshield, right? No one answers. Chuckie turns once more to the Rent-a-Cop whose body still twitches in some final death throe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just DIE ?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises the gun. Another shot explodes into the night. 46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della flinches but no   bullet tears through the back of skull. She slams into   the driver's seat and punches the lock switch. She hits   the four wheel drive button and p the accelerator pedal   to the metal. The Explorer barely protests as its front tires claw and bounce over the six inch concrete row barrier. The barrie screeches along the underside of the frame. There is a lo SCRAAAAAPE noise as the car heaves over the barrier. Then the rear wheels bounce and claw over. The car fishtails momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please God. Don't overcorrect. She releases the pressure on the accelerator. The Explore straightens. 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomas screams at Chuckie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinga tu madre. She making her getaway. All except Chuckie turn to look as Della accelerates acro the unfinished outskirts of the car park behind them. Vinh tugs at Chuckie's sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie! But Chuckie's staring at the bloody mess he made, with a faraway look in his eyes, like he's disassociating. Vinh throws down the stub of his cigarette, follows Tomas into the Plymouth. Tomas guns the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She on her cell right now calling the pigs. Huey's almost hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We going down for this! Chuckie turns on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gone buck wild, nigga? We ain't going down for shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't earned the right to call me a nigga. And that goes for all you haters. Behind him Della's car turns onto the mall's outer perime service road in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy my G. Easy. Chuckie cajoles Huey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is our bitch, right? Huey calms down. Chuckie gently pushes him into the Plymouth back seat bes Vinh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in my fallen soldier. Chuckie opens the driver door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shove over Tomas. You know I front the ride. Tomas shuffles over to the passenger seat. Chuckie climbs into driver side. Doors slam. The Plymouth screeches acro the parking lot and exits onto the service road. 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Della speeds down the long dark empty service road which skims the deserted warehouses at the back of the Mall. Between the warehouses are dark patches of undeveloped la No Mans land. Not a car nor a person in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It starts to rain. 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes the cell phone trying to revive its dead batte Types 911 in anyway. No connection. No response. She shak it some more. Gives up. She relentlessly checks the rearview and side mirrors as races into the rainy night. The driving conditions are not good, poor visibility ahea Too bad. She speeds anyway. The road has to connect to a main road soon! Another glance in the rearview. Nothing. Side mirror. Sti clear. Once more in the rearview. Headlights!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Side mirror. It's the Plymouth. She presses the accelerator down harder. The engine revs. In the rearview there's a sudden flash above her rear lef headlight. And another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
